smell_analysis.justification: The diagram 'Õpingukavade allsüsteem' on page 16 and the heading page 'Õpingukavade AB disaini diagramm (õpingukava sündmus)' on page 28 contain only the diagram titles and no visible classes, tables, use cases, states, or relationships, so the model includes empty diagrams.

In the use case diagrams 'Õpingukavade allsüsteemi kasutusjuhtude diagramm' (page 17) and 'Vastuvõtuaegade allsüsteemi kasutusjuhtude diagramm' (page 18), every named use case appears in the midst of association multiplicities, include-relations, or textual descriptions that reference actors (e.g., 'identifitseerib ennast', 'arvab kuulajaskonnast välja'), and there is no clearly isolated use case oval without any actor connections.

Across both use case diagrams, each use case name describes a distinct activity (such as 'Õpingukava koostamine', 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Teatele vastamine', 'Lisa vastuvõtuaeg', 'Tühista vastuvõtule tulek') and there is no pair of differently worded use cases that obviously describe the same activity while being associated with the same actor.

The PDF does not contain any explicit package diagrams; all structural diagrams are class or database/entity diagrams, so there is no package diagram where multiple model elements share the same primary name in the same package.

Where the same logical identifiers occur in multiple tables (for example 'matrikli_nr' in 'Yliopilane' and in link tables on pages 25, 26, 30, and 31), the diagrams show corresponding foreign key connectors and FK annotations between the tables; there is no clear case where the same data value is stored redundantly in multiple tables without a foreign key relationship.

Use case naming is inconsistent: some use cases start with an imperative verb, such as 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Registreeri vastuvõtule tulek', 'Tühista vastuvõtule tulek', 'Lisa vastuvõtuaeg', while others are noun or noun-phrase forms like 'Õpingukava koostamine', 'Õpingukava esitamine', 'Semestrite haldamine', 'Õpingukavade kinnitamine', and 'Kuulajaskonna vaatamine' on pages 17–18.

In the state diagrams 'Õpingukava seisundidiagramm' (pages 4 and 9) and 'Vastuvõtuaja seisundidiagramm' (pages 12 and 14), all listed states (e.g., 'Koostamisel', 'Aktuaalne', 'Täiendamisel', 'Kustutatud', 'Vaba', 'Hõivatud', 'Aegunud', 'Tühistatud') have associated transition descriptions and appear as part of the transition structure; there is no state that is clearly isolated without any incoming transition from an initial state.

The activity diagrams 'Õpingukava koostamise tegevusdiagramm' (page 15), 'Vastuvõtule tuleku registreerimine' (page 19), and 'Vastuvõtule tuleku tühistamine' (page 20) show each action node (such as 'Õpingukava koostamine', 'Eksmatrikuleerimine', 'Registreerib enda vastuvõtule tuleku', 'Valib tühistatava vastuvõtule tuleku') described in the flow of decisions and guards; no action appears as a standalone node without incoming control flow from earlier steps.

On the class-style overview diagrams 'Õpingukavade FASiga seotud pädevusalad ja registrid' (page 2) and 'Vastuvõtuaegade FASiga seotud pädevusalad ja registrid' (page 3), relationships between the central subsystem box and the surrounding register classes and actors are drawn with textual labels like 'Loeb' and 'Teenindab' but have no multiplicity indicators (no '1' or '0..*') and no crow's-foot or FK notation at either end, so these relationships lack multiplicities on both ends.

Several class/database diagrams display ten or more central elements. For example, the conceptual diagram 'Õpingukavade_registri_kontseptuaalne_diagramm_1' on page 6 contains at least 17 entities (Isik, Amet, Aine_õpingukavas, Õppekava, Õpingukava, Üliõpilane, Piirang, etc.), and the database design diagrams for Õpingukava and Õppekava on pages 30–31 each include more than ten tables.

Across the class and database diagrams, no single class or table is visibly connected to six or more distinct relationship lines on the same diagram; even heavily connected elements like 'Õpingukava' in the Õpingukava AB design diagram (page 30) appear to have at most five separate connectors to other tables.

The diagrams generally place related elements in relatively compact clusters (for example, tables arranged around 'Õpingukava' on page 30 and the cluster around 'Vastuvõtt' on page 26), and there is no clear instance where the distance between a related pair is more than twice the apparent average distance between elements on the same diagram.

Many use case names and activity actions do not begin with an active verb. Examples include 'Õpingukava koostamine', 'Õpingukava esitamine', 'Semestrite haldamine', 'Õpingukavade kinnitamine', and 'Õpingukavade muutmine mitteaktuaalseks' in the use case diagram on page 17 and the action 'Esitamata jätmise põhjendamine' in the activity diagram on page 15, all of which start with a noun phrase rather than a verb.

All class, table, attribute, and use case names contain more than three characters; even the shortest central names such as 'Isik', 'Ruum', 'Hoone', 'Teade', 'Vastus', and 'Aktuaalne' exceed three characters, while very short tokens like 'PK', 'FK', and 'dm' are stereotypes or diagram type abbreviations rather than element names.

Several entity and table names that represent singular domain objects start with a lowercase letter, such as 'moodul_r', 'haridusaste_r', 'aine_opingukavas', 'aine_tyypopingukavas', 'opingukava', 'yliopilane', and 'tootaja' in the AB design diagrams on pages 27, 29, 30, and 31, violating the convention that class names should start with an uppercase letter.

Attribute and column names throughout the diagrams consistently begin with lowercase letters or with allowed technical prefixes (e.g., 'ruum_id', 'korrus', 'matrikli_nr', 'toimumise_kuupaev'); there are no attributes or columns whose identifiers start with an uppercase letter.

Database table/entity names that represent singular domain objects are given in singular form (e.g., 'Isik', 'Yliopilane', 'Tootaja', 'Ruum', 'Hoone', 'Vastuvott', 'Oppekava'); the plural words are used only in register names like 'Isikute register' or 'Üliõpilaste register', which are domain registers and are exempt from this rule.

Class, table, and attribute names do not use type-indicating prefixes such as 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'str'; naming patterns like 'moodul_r', 'aine_opingukavas', 'tootaja_id', and 'matrikli_nr' either use suffixes or descriptive words, and the only prefixes present (e.g., 'PK', 'FK', 'pfK', 'idx_') are for keys and indexes or are explicitly allowed.
